metadata.title: Advanced electron microscopy characterization of nanomaterials for catalysis

sections.text:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) has become one of the most powerful techniques in the fields of material science, inorganic chemistry and nanotechnology. In terms of resolutions, advanced TEM may reach a high spatial resolution of 0.05 nm, a high energy-resolution of 7 meV. In addition, in situ TEM can help researchers to image the process happened within 1 ms. This paper reviews the recent technical progresses of applying advanced TEM characterization on nanomaterials for catalysis. The text is organized based on the perspective of application: for example, size, composition, phase, strain, and morphology. The electron beam induced effect and in situ TEM are also introduced. I hope this review can help the scientists in related fields to take advantage of advanced TEM to their own researches. © 2017, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Keywords: Advanced TEM; Nanomaterials; Catalysts; In situ

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Advanced transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a powerful and fast-growing technique to probe the local structure and chemistry of materials [1e5]. Suffice it to say that the invention and development of aberration correction system has been the most prominent progress in the field of electron microscopy in the past decade. Recent applications of TEM have benefitted from aberration correction, especially on energy-related fields [6e15]. There are three main kinds of TEM techniques such as imaging techniques: including high resolution TEM, scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) imaging, and 3D electron tomography technique; spectroscopy techniques: including X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS), and TEM-cathodoluminescence microscopy (TEMCL); diffraction techniques: including selected area electron diffraction (SAED), nano-beam electron diffraction (NBED),

and convergent beam electron diffraction (CBED) as well as their combinations. Since these techniques are particularly suitable for certain structural characterization, it is important to understand their merits and be aware how to combine these techniques to solve certain questions. Sometimes, how to solve certain questions using TEM-based techniques is not straightforward as one suspected. For example, a common problem which has been widely seen in literatures is to directly measure lattice constants from high resolution TEM images for phase identification. Actually, this kind of measurement should be cautiously interpreted with the help of other techniques. Here, I will summarize recently published results on the relationship between the structure and properties of metallic catalysts from the prospective of TEM. I supposed the readers have basic knowledge about transmission electron microscopy and material science. For transmission electron microscopy techniques themselves, there are already excellent books and reviews [15e22]. This review focusing on the applications of metallic nano-catalysts, will introduce advanced electron microscopy techniques from the perspective of

catalysis rather than the in-depth technical discussions. I emphasize in this essay the strategy and basic principles in the design and interpretation of TEM characterization. Last, within such limited space, this paper could not cover all TEMrelated techniques or applications, but instead put an emphasis on representative works published in the last several years.
Metallic nanoparticles and nano-structured catalysts have traditionally played a critical role in guaranteeing the effectiveness of industrial heterogeneous catalysis [23e25]. The design and synthesis of new nanocatalysts will require fundamental understanding of the relationship between their catalytic properties (activity, stability, selectivity, etc.) and their structure. The optimization of the catalysts' properties can only be realized by precise understanding and control over size, composition, phase, strain, and morphology of nanomaterials. I will introduce how to investigate these issues consequently in practice. Then I will introduce some critical issues for TEM-based study: the electron-beam effect and interfacial issue. The last part would be discussing about the in situ TEM approaches which have been drawn intensive attention in recent years.

sections.heading: 2. Size distribution
sections.text:
Size distribution of nanomaterials is simple but important information. It is well known that the portion of surface atoms will increase with decreasing the size. The averaged particle size (assuming the particle is crystalline in nature) can be calculated from X-ray diffraction (XRD) by using linebroadening fitting with Scherrer equation, and such results are usually averaged over the entire sample. In comparison, TEM/STEM images provide more localized information, and from TEM/STEM images at proper magnification, one can retrieve the size distribution directly by simply counting the particles with different sizes. As shown in Fig. 1, size distribution of ZrO2 NPs is determined from the HAADF images, matching the average particles size estimated from XRD. When measuring the size of particles, different shape models (such as sphere, square, and oval) can be applied [26]. Software or scripts could be very helpful when counting a large number of particles, such as Image J [27]. From the size distribution, the statistical analysis can be performed based on different models. For example, the average number (d), surface (ds), and volume (dv) of nanoparticles can be retrieved from the TEM/STEM image using the following equations [28]: d ¼ P i di

sections.heading: 3. Compositional distribution
sections.text:
The composition of materials is normally determined using X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) or electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS). The compositional distribution can be well characterized using either STEM-EELS or
STEM-EDS. With the modern STEM system, it is possible to simultaneously collect the annular dark-field (ADF) signals from the ADF detector and particular elemental signals from either the EELS or EDS detectors. By scanning the electron probe on the nanocatalyst, with the modes of line profile (1D) or mapping (2D), one can obtain the elemental distribution. The EDS signal gives a better quantification results because it has a low background. Obviously, the spatial resolution of the line profile or mapping is decided by the step of scanning or the electron-beam size whichever is bigger. With the probe aberration corrector, one can have atomic resolution STEMEELS or STEM-EDS mappings, but only for thin samples. Traditionally, EELS is better to identify light elements and EDS is believed better to be used for detecting heavy elements [18]. However, this is not always right for nano-catalysts. For a certain EELS/EDS detector, the signal to noise ratio (SNR) of the final mapping depends on the collection time, energy dispersion and electron beam current. The experimental parameters for STEM-EELS/STEM-EDS collection need to be carefully selected according to the interested element, the sample geography (size, support, shape, etc.) and the acceleration voltage of microscope. For example, a large energydispersion of STEM-EELS can be used for heavy elements mapping. Fig. 2 shows the high angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-STEM image and STEM-EELS mapping of Ag@Au concave cuboctahedra nanoparticles [29]. This work has been performed using a Hitachi-2700C dedicated STEM with CEOS probe aberration-corrector and a cold-field emission gun. For HAADF-STEM imaging, the contrast(brightness/darkness) is proportional to the averaged atomic number Zn (n ¼ 1.4e2 depending on the experimental condition) along the beam [30]. Since the atomic numbers of Ag and Au are 47 and 79, respectively, we observed a brighter contrast at the end of nano particle. Preferential distribution of Au at surface is confirmed by STEM-EELS mapping of Au. Here, a very large energy-dispersion (1.25 eV/CH) and the probe current of 150 pA are exploited, which allows to acquire a reasonable elemental map with 100 pixels by 100 pixels at a dwelling time of 0.04 s. In this case, the total collection time is less than 10 min and its efficiency is comparable to (or even superior than) the results taken with a modern EDS detector (0.9 srad). In summary, two kinds of techniques are applied in order to adequately characterize Ag@Au nanoparticles: HAADF-STEM imaging which gives Z-/thickness-contrast in high spatial resolution and STEM-EELS mapping which gives a true elemental mapping for most elements which has a characterization peak below ~2900 eV. For HAADF-STEM imaging, (1) it can not distinguish the elements with close atomic numbers. (2) its contrast also depends on the local thickness/shape. On the other hand, STEM-EELS mapping has a lower spatial resolution depending on the numbers of pixels, but can give detailed chemical information on the local bonding at high energy-resolution. This feature is particularly useful to probe the valence states of 3d metals from their L edges' fine features. This method has been widely used in investigating the electrode materials for batteries where the redox reaction during charge/discharge is indeed realized by
the valence change of 3d metals. In principle, the information from the fine structure of EELS, named energy loss near edge structure (ELNES) is equivalent to that from the fine structure of X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) [22]. The theoretical calculation for the XAS can be used to interpret the feature of ELNES. A qualitative comparison between experimental results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations can be very helpful to understand the nature of bonding; however, technical difficulties in the calculation part have been raised for the quantitative explanations.

sections.heading: 4. Phase identification
sections.text:
For solid matter, a phase is a form of matter with uniform composition and uniform physical properties. Structurally, it means the uniform lattice sequence with same lattice parameters. For the crystalline materials with a relative large grain size (> 5 nm), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) is powerful to identify the local phases [31]. Since the measured value may have as much as 5% error, if possible, I would suggest one always to compare their electron diffraction results with the results from X-ray diffraction techniques. Otherwise, an internal reference phase is necessary for a highprevision investigation [32]. However, in cases that (1) the
grain size is very small (2) the crystallinity is poor, (3) multiple similar phases are presented, both X-ray diffraction and SAED techniques may have difficulties to identify the phases. While high resolution (HR-) TEM imaging can be very useful to distinguish known phases [33,34], HR-STEM imaging may have a less precision than HRTEM due to the scanning distortions as well as the sample drifting. Again, a quantitative measurement of the lattice parameters from HRTEM would need a reference phase with known lattice parameters in the same image. In Fig. 3, we characterized the surface reduced Ni on NiO nanoplates [35]. This reduction happened with a conversion reaction with Na ions (NiO þ 2Naþ / Na2O þ Ni). High resolution STEM image, FFT and modeling at Fig. 3(aec) identified the reaction and a lattice correlation was found. Further results from 3D electron tomography in Fig. 3(d) and STEM-EELS mapping (Fig. S4 in Ref. 35) show the reaction happened only on the surface of NiO. This case highlights the combination of analytical TEM methods to identify the reaction nature.

sections.heading: 5. Morphology
sections.text:
For nanomaterial, morphology indicates the shape and surface facets. Nanoparticles (0D), nanorod/nanowire/
nanotube (1D), and nanoplates/nano-sheet (2D) represent distinct shape of nanocrystal, which consequently enables the control of the activity or stability of catalysts [36]. For a large nanocrystal with regular shape, the morphological information of shape can be obtained from the SEM image or coherent synchrotron X-ray techniques. Due to SEM's limited resolution, the shape of a small nanocrystal can only be resolved with TEM [37]. It is acknowledged that the TEM/STEM images represent a 2D projection of a 3D objective through a
dynamical interference process. Although the process of the electron beam scattering is much more complicated than the process in optical microscopy, after proper data analysis (reconstruction), the 3D morphology (shape, orientation, facet, etc.) of nanoparticles with regular shape can be directly determined from the HRTEM imaging from one or several projections [37e39]. As shown in Fig. 4, a variety of Ag polyhedrons are produced by the same reaction using a spherical gold seed. These particular {111}-faceted particle
shapes are all related in that they consist of 2, 5, or 20 tetrahedral subunits, separated by twin boundaries [39]. As the bimetallic nanostructures grew, twin structures were successively developed, resulting in formation of multiply-twinned nanoparticles from single-crystalline seeds. Clearly, the STEM investigation performed by Langille et al. revealed the elemental distribution during the growth, benefiting from the Z-contrast imaging. In general, there are three main TEM approaches to obtain the 3D morphology information of nanocrystal: (1) Exit wave reconstruction allows one to reconstruct the 3D structure from a series of HRTEM images with different focus [40]. (2) Direct reconstruction from modeling atomic resolution HAADF-STEM images [41]. (3) 3D STEM tomography by titling the specimen [42e45]. The applications of the first two approaches, which are able to provide atomic 3D information, are currently limited within some certain specimens while the 3D STEM tomography have been considerably developed to achieve atomic resolution: atomic electron tomography (AET) [46e51]. AET has also revealed the existence of atomic steps at 3D twin boundaries as well as the 3D core structure of edge and screw dislocations. Fig. 5 shows an schematic layout of AET and its representative products. The tilt series of ADF-STEM images
are obtained from tilting the sample along a tilt axis. After correcting same drift, scan distortion and denoising, the tilt series are aligned using a center-of-mass method. Then the 3D reconstruction is calculated from back-projection method. Iterative algorithms are finally performed to produce the fine 3D atomic model. Fig. 5 (top right) shows an approach of algorithm interating between real and Fourier space. A successful AET reconstruction may reveal unique information, for example, the 3D position of individual atoms, defects structure in 3D, atomic strains in 3D and even the 3D structure of heterogeneous nanoparticles in solutions [48e51].
It is well known that the catalytic reaction happens on the surface of catalyst. Therefore the surface structures (facets, surface steps and composition) of catalysts are of primary importance. Finding the possible surface facets is the first necessary step and often not an easy task for any nanocrystals. The reason is simple: TEM/STEM images are the 2D projection of 3D matter. The edge plane of the 2D image is not necessary the facet plane of the 3D project. One has to find the orientation where the facet is parallel to the electron beam (edge-on position). For a regular shaped crystal, information of surface facet can be directly obtained from the SEM or TEM/STEM image at edge-on conditions [29,37]. Otherwise
3D electron tomography may help to find the facet planes [52,53]. Further, the surface composition within one monolayer can be obtained from the STEM-EELS mapping [54,55]. Although beautiful results have been demonstrated to retrieve the atomic structure of surface, it is still a challenging issue for most materials. Different to scanning tuning microscopy (STM) where the energy of involved electrons is quite low, the electron beam of TEM has energy of hundreds of thousand eV. In addition, the beam-induced effects and surface dynamics induced subsidiary factors during experiment should be paid attention in practical work.

sections.heading: 6. Electron-beam effect
sections.text:
High voltage electron beam of TEM may interact with matter (either nuclei or electrons) and induce certain structural changes in the TEM sample. These kinds of changes can be either temporary or permanent in the surface or in bulk [56e58], named as electron-beam induced damage. This kind of damage may be very severe for the samples containing certain elements or molecules, such as alkali, organic, water, etc. and for certain techniques which require a long collection time, such as 3D electron tomography, STEM-EDS or STEM-
EELS mapping. Fig. 6(a) and (b) show a high resolution HAADF-STEM image taken from a electron-beam damaged region of a Li4Ti5O12 nanoparticle (with a dose rate of 1.5 105 A/m2 and an accelerate voltage of 200 kV). It is observed a phase change from spinel to rocksalt at the damaged region (marked by green square) [59]. In principle, we can catalog the damaging effects by which are originated from elastic scattering or inelastic scattering. For metallic materials on carbon grid, the charge induced by incident electrons is delocalized; thus, there is no charge accumulation process. In this case, the inelastic process (including radiolysis effect) is suppressed and the elastic scattering with the nuclei plays the dominant role. Only if the energy transferred from the incident electron to the atom is larger than Ed, the atom in the specimen can be displaced (damaged) where Ed is the energy transfer that is required for atomic displacement. On the other hand, the elastic process (knock-on effects) involves only certain transfer of energy and momentum from fast electrons to atoms through an elastic collision (not all kinetic energy of fast electrons can be transferred to the atom). The total damage rate depends on acceleration voltage, the irradiation time, the electron beam dose and the composition/geometry of the sample. Since the surface atoms may
have less bonding comparing to the bulk atoms, the surface of nanocrystal are observed to be easily damaged comparing to the bulk part. For given samples, I believe that the damage is depending on both total irradiation dose (determined by irradiation time) and the dose rate (decided by the beam intensity) as shown in Fig. 6(c). In practice, lowering the electron beam intensity and shortening illustration time (dose rate and dose respectively) can minimize the electron-beam damage. In some cases, electron beam can promote the phase transitions of nanoparticles and this change can be monitored from the change in either TEM/STEM images or EELS [59,60]. As a practical suggestion, one should intentionally irradiate any unknown samples with different beam intensity to figure out the optimized conditions, which is appropriate to acquire reasonable data as well as bring about negligible beam effect. Otherwise, the electron beam induced damage may dominate in the TEM results. Normally, the electron beam damage happens easier in the thin region than in the thick region. This is because for a given damaging rate and certain beam intensity, the ratio between damaged atoms and undamaged atoms is higher in the thin region, therefore the damage in the thin region is much easier to be recognized. The electron-beam induced damage holds the fundamental
limitation to the resolution and even possibility of most TEMbased techniques.

sections.heading: 7. Interfacial structure and strain
sections.text:
The nature of interface plays an essential role in governing the characteristics of epitaxial thin films for energy harvesting. It also largely determines the activity and stability of catalytic behaviors of coreeshell, alloyed, and composited catalysts as well as the electrode materials for batteries. In the later case, how ions diffuse through the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is not fully understood. Although the interfacial structure can be analyzed using vibrational spectroscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and atomic force microscopy, TEM can give unique information in atomic scale. Fig. 7 shows a case of coreeshell nanoplates of PtPbePt, where the structure model is constructed using combined TEM techniques [11]. First, by modeling the SAED patterns and considering the results of STEM-EELS mapping, we can prove the core is a hexagonal structured PtPb (with space group, P6/mmc) and cubic Pt (with space group, Pm3m) surrounds the core. This result is also confirmed by high-resolution TEM images and the selected area FFT
patterns. Then the orientational relationship between PtPb core and Pt shell can be deduced as [001]PtPb//[110]Pt and [100]PtPb//[001]Pt. There are two cubic-on-hexagonal interfaces existed: (001)PtPb//(110)Pt between core and top (bottom) and (010)PtPb//(110)Pt between core and edges. These interfaces are very different to the common cubic-oncubic interfaces (for example, Pb@Pt or Au@Pt). The atomic structure of interfaces can be investigated using HRSTEM as shown in Fig. 7(cef) and atomic models of interfaces have been built accordingly (Fig. 7(g) and Fig. S3 in Ref. 11). A large biaxial strain can be deduced from the SAED and FFT patterns: including compressive strain along 〈110〉Pt and tensile strain along 〈100〉Pt. It was found this unique strain nature has a significant effect on enhancing its activity as the electrocatalysts for fuel cell. The control of interfaces has been reported as an efficient approach in developing high performance catalyst for fuel cell, for example, the cubic-on-hexagonal interface at Ru@Pt [61], the ordered core and Pt interfaces at FePt@Pt and Pt3Co@Pt [62,63].
Strain is also an important issue affecting the performance of batteries. Besides X-ray techniques [64,65], the quantitative
measurement of local strain can be achieved from either SAED patterns or the high resolution TEM images [11,66e69]. Especially, geometry phase analysis (GPA) method may help to retrieve the strain at a precision of 0.03 Å [70].
8. In-situ electron microscopy
In situ TEM provides key information on the structural dynamics of a material during reactions or transformations at much higher spatial resolution than any other in situ techniques [71,72]. Further, in operando TEM experiment allows one to observe the structural changes while measuring the catalytic performance; therefore, it is possible to directly link structure-processing-property interrelationship. Since in operando TEM demands a careful design of the reaction conditions, a number of intriguing approaches are under development. In situ TEM provides great opportunities to characterize solid-state batteries, ferroelectric and ferromagnetic switching and behavior, and mechanical properties under applied heat, stress, optical excitation, and magnetic or electric fields [9,35,73e78]. Here I will mainly focus on the principles and setups of environmental TEM, including liquid and gas
ambience, which are important for the characterization of catalysis.
The study on the reaction at the gasesolid interface in situ with TEM would give the direct mechanistic information on how catalysts work [78e89]. The challenge of this technique is maintaining the high vacuum at TEM column when the gas is introduced into the specimen area since the high energy electron beam requires a high vacuum to avoid undesirable scattering from gas molecules. There are two main technical approaches to solve this problem: (1) specially designed environmental TEM equipped with pumped vacuum systems. (2) Sealed gas cell integrated with special TEM holder. The details of these two approaches can be found in Ref. [85] and [88]. Fig. 8(a) shows a schematic diagram of a differentially pumped TEM column [85]. The function of this differentially pumped vacuum system is to keep a high vacuum at the electron source while the gas is pumped into the specimen area. Between the electron source and specimen area, there are three turbo pumps to keep the pressure difference between them. A pressure difference as high as 106 order can be reached in a FEI-Titan environmental TEM Titan 80-300 (ETEM) in Center for Functionl Nanomaterials at Brookhaven National Laboratory. A picture of differentially pumped vacuum system is shown in Fig. 8(b). Obviously, the integrated pump system would increase the complexity of the TEM system and the gas flow or pump system should be carefully designed to minimize the possible vibration introduced by them. The current E-TEM can obtain atomic resolution TEM image at a high temperature of 1000 C and a gas atmosphere of few thousands of Pa. A fast and stable CCD camera, for
example, Gatan-K2 may further improve the quality of TEM imaging under certain vibration.
The environmental TEM can study the reactions at a few millibars but can not reach the level of ambient pressure. For investigating the gasesolid reactions occurring at a higher pressure, one can use a windowed TEM cell attached to specialized TEM holder. Based on microelectromechanical system (MEMS) technique, Creemer et al. designed a “nanoreactor”, as shown in Fig. 9 [88]. In this nanoreactor, 10 nm SiNx films are used for the top/bottom windows. This nanoreactor allows researchers to heat the sample to 500 C and introduce 1.2 bar of H2 to the sample. They have achieved a spatial resolution of 0.18 nm at Cu particles on ZnO at 300 kV. More advanced design of pressure gas cell is under rapid development and many designs have been commercialized. Although the windowed cell may reduce the spatial resolution of TEM, it is possible/easier approach to study dynamics of reaction in operando. A recent report has explored the possibility to combine the X-ray technique and TEM in operando to study the reaction dynamics [90].
Using TEM to study the liquid reactions has experienced a surge of interest, but at the same time encountered lots of technical challenges. It is obvious that an open environmental chamber approach can not to be implemented in most TEM experiments unless these liquids have very low-vaporpressure. On the other hand, the liquid cells have been designed with the new development of thin-film and microfabrication techniques [50,91e99]. Thin carbon foils or graphene sheets have been used as membranes, and thin (10e50 nm) SiNx films supported on silicon microchips
become increasingly popular. The liquid cell designed by Zheng et al. is shown in Fig. 10. In this design, the thickness of window itself may limit the spatial resolution [93,95]. The formation of bubbles in the liquid layer may cause problems.
Uncontrolled bubble formation may be alleviated by flowing the liquid through the cell, and the reduction of liquid thickness can actually improve the resolution [92]. In spite of unsolved problems, liquid cell enables researchers to observe the
growth of metallic nanocrystals at atomic resolution in liquid media, induced either by electron beam or heating [92e98].
The growth of Pt3Fe nanowires from nanoparticles has been studied within a liquid cell as shown in Fig. 11 [96]. Three distinct stages of growth can be identified. During the first stage, many small nanoparticles are formed. Subsequently, the second stage of growth is dominated by nanoparticles forming nanoparticle chains. In the final stage, adjacent nanoparticles within the chain contact with each other, forming a neck while surfactant molecules are excluded. The liquid cell technique enables direct observation of the dynamic growth of nanoparticles/nanorods in solution using TEM and provides fundamental understanding the nanostructures and to rational design of nanocatalysts with controlled properties. However, quantitative data acquisition is the key challenge for electron microscopy of liquid samples, in particular if we want to understand the fine details of static structures and to test models for dynamic processes. In addition, a more rigorous understanding of electron beameliquid/precursor interactions is also important. With the advance of the liquid cell techniques, numerous exciting developments can be expected in the near future. For example, the electrochemical cells have been developed to study the reaction dynamics in lithium ion batteries [100e102]. Besides the TEM techniques of electron diffraction and imaging, in situ STEM and EELS techniques are also being developed to retrieve chemical information during the reaction.

sections.heading: 9. Summary
sections.text:
In this review, we summarized the applications of TEM on nanomaterials for catalysis from the practical prospective. Transmission electron microscopy is currently a fast-growing field [103]. A recent report funded by U. S. Department of Energy has identified three main directions of advanced electron microscopy: multi-dimensional atomic resolution microscopy and analysis, ultrafast imaging and diffraction, and modular in situ and in operando dynamic microscopy and analysis [104]. The characterization for nanomaterial catalysts can be benefited from the instrumental developments as well as the big data approach [105], though this review mentioned only a portion of these new developments. Here I want to emphasize the practical strategy to perform TEM investigation: (1) Before we start to TEM work, it is important to collect and even analyze the information about the targeted sample, including the possible phase and the possible beaminduced effects. (2) We need to understand the limitation and possible practical issues of each TEM technique, and be cautious to interpret the TEM results without simulation. (3) One should be cautious to link the TEM results (which are from small regions) with the bulk properties. The model/hypothesis should be compared with results from other characterization techniques.

metadata.abstractText: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) has become one of the most powerful techniques in the fields of material science, inorganic chemistry and nanotechnology. In terms of resolutions, advanced TEM may reach a high spatial resolution of 0.05 nm, a high energy-resolution of 7 meV. In addition, in situ TEM can help researchers to image the process happened within 1 ms. This paper reviews the recent technical progresses of applying advanced TEM characterization on nanomaterials for catalysis. The text is organized based on the perspective of application: for example, size, composition, phase, strain, and morphology. The electron beam induced effect and in situ TEM are also introduced. I hope this review can help the scientists in related fields to take advantage of advanced TEM to their own researches. © 2017, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
